div.p: Milke for Babes.
OR, A North-Countrie Catechiſme.

p.hi: Made plaine and eaſiy, to the Capacitie of the Countrie people.

div.p: The ſecond Impreſſion.
By WILLIAM CRASHAVV, Batchellor in Diuinity, and Preacher of the Word.
LONDON, Printed by NICHOLAS OKES, and are to be ſold by Thomas Langley, at his ſhop ouer againſt the Sarazens head without Newgate. 1618.

div.head: TO The Right VVorſhipful, Sir Henry Griffith, of Agnes Burton, Knight, one of his Maieſties Counſell in the North, and Deputie Lieutenant, in the Eaſt-Riding, and William Saint-Quintin of Harpham Eſquire, Grace and peace.
div.p:
SEeing they that liue vnder you for their eſtates and bodies, are vnder my cure and care for their ſoules, you will giue mee leaue (nay thankes I am ſure) to be as carefull for the better part as
you I hope are and wil be for the worſe: You know it were a ſhame to you, if they could iuſtly ſay they were not able to liue and eate their bread vnder you their Lords: and more were it to me their Paſtor, if they wanted either the Milke, or the Meate fit for their ſoules.

To this end ſeeing I finde, that Catechiſing is the life of Preaching, and ſuch a meanes of knowledge as without it all preaching is to little purpoſe, I haue heere dreſt them their firſt diſh, euen a meaſe of Milke (the old, plaine and good meate of our forefathers) I meane this ſhort and eaſie Catechiſme: Not as making a new one, for hat were a needleſſe preſumption but as a helpe to vnderſtand that good Catechiſme giuen
vs already in the Common Prayer Booke.

Now ſeeing your experience in your families, and mine in the whole Pariſh hath found the benefit of Catechiſing to be ſo extraordinary, wee haue cauſe to acknowledge the godly wiſdome and care of our Church Gouernours in commanding the performance of that duty in euery Pariſh: which if it were duely obſerued ouer all the Land, I dare ſay, where there is no Preaching the want would be leſſe hurtfull, and where it is, the benefit much more aboundant. And let it worke in you a care, Gen 18. not onely as good Abrahams, to command your families, but (ſeeing you are here Magiſtrates and Lords) like zealous Dauids, Pſal. 110. to take order that your people
and tenants doe frequent this godly exerciſe, which by Gods good bleſſing ſhall by mee, or my ſufficient Deputy bee continually kept vp, as the time and ſeaſon of the yeare will permit. This will make our Sermons at home, and our Exerciſes abroad much more profitable and effectuall, your Seruants and Tenants more faithfull to God, and more ſeruiceable to your ſelues. And when they finde themſelues mercifully delt withall by you their Land-lords for their bodies: and good prouiſion, both of Milke and ſtrong meate for their ſoules: Their Iob. 31. 20. Loynes (as Iob ſaith) ſhall bleſſe you, their hearts loue mee, and their ſoules and all within them ſhall praiſe God for vs both: and their Neighbours about
them ſhall ſay. Bleſſed are the people that be in ſuch a caſe, yea thrice happy the people that haue the Lord for their God. Now praying that both you and I, and they that follow vs may ſtriue to deſerue this honour, and enioy this comfort; and our people receiue this double bleſſing by vs,

closer.signed: I reſt Your Paſtor and ſeruant in Chriſt, WILLIAM CRASHAVV.

div.head: Saint Pauls words applyable to many of the people and profeſſors in England.
div.p: VVHereas in regard of the time, Heb. 5, 12, 13, 14. you ought to be teachers, you haue need that one teach you the firſt principles of the Oracles of GOD, and are ſuch as haue need of Milke, and not of ſtrong Meate: for euery one that vſeth Milke, is vnskilfull in the Word of Righteouſneſſe, for he is a Babe. But ſtrong Meate belongeth to them that are of full age, euen thoſe which by reaſon of vſe, are exerciſed to diſcerne of good and euill Heb. 5, 12, 13, 14.

div.head: Saint Peters exhortation, which I direct chiefly to the people of the North.
div.p: LAy aſide all Malice, all Guile 1 Pet. 2. 1, 2, 3. and Hypocriſies, and Enuies, and euill ſpeakings. And as new borne Babes, deſire the ſincere Milke of the Word, that you may grow thereby, now that you haue taſted how gratious the Lord is. 1. Pet. 2. 1, 2, 3.

head.hi: Milke for Babes. OR, A ſhort Countrie Catechiſme.

argument.p: What Man is.

head.hi: Queſtion. VVHat art thou?

div.p: Anſwer. A Chriſtian man.

head.hi: Q. Who made thee a man?

div.p: A. God by his power and wiſdome Pſal. 100, 3..

head.hi: Q. Who made thee a Chriſtian?

div.p:
A. God in his loue and mercy Epheſ. 1, 17.
•• d 24, 5..

head.hi: Q. What ought a Chriſtian man to know?

div.p: A. Two things, God and himſelfe Phil. 3..

head.hi: Q. Tell me then, what is man?

div.p: Anſ. A principall Creature of God, conſiſting of a reaſonable ſoule, and humane body Eccleſ. 12, 7..

head.hi: Q. What is the ſoule?

div.p: A. A ſpirituall, inuiſible, and immortall creature, created in Gods Image, giuing life, breath, and being to the body Gen. 1, 26 27, and 2, 7..

head.hi: Q. What is the body?

div.p: A. A corporall, viſible and corruptible creature, the houſe and inſtrument of the, ſoule 2 Cor. 5, 1..

argument.p: What GOD is.

head.hi: Q. VVHat is GOD?

div.p: A. What GOD is in himſelfe, cannot be knowne Ioh. 1, 18.

head.hi: Q. Why can we not know what GOD is?

div.p: A. Becauſe he is inuiſible and infinite 1 Tim. 1 16,.

head.hi: Q. How then is GOD to bee knowne?

div.p:
A. Onely ſo farre foorth, as hee
hath vouchſafed to reueale of himſelfe Exod. 33, 23..

head.hi: Q. What benefit is it to man to know God?

div.p: A. Excéeding great, for it is tho onely ſure way to attaine eternall life and happineſſe.

head.hi: Q. How hath God reuealed himſelfe?

div.p: A. In his wordes and in his workes Pſal. 19, 1.

argument.p: Of Gods Word.

head.hi: Q. VVHat is Gods Word?

div.p: A. Gods Word is contained in that bleſſed Booke that is called the Holy Bible Deut. 4, 2 Prou. 30, 5, 6 Reu. 22, 18, 19.

head.hi: Q. Why is that Booke called Gods Word?

div.p: A. Becauſe GOD made it, and it containes Gods will, as a mans words declare his minde Pſal. 147, 19 20 Rom. 3, 2.

head.hi: Q. But why is it called the Holy Bible, or holy Scripture?

div.p:
A. Moſt worthily, for 1. The
moſt holy God made it Pſal. 68, 114.. 2. Holy men wrote it 2 Pet. 1, 20.. 3. The matter it handles is holy Pſal. 119. 140.. 4. It makes them holy, that loue to reade it Ioh. 17, 27..

head.hi: Q. How did God make it?

div.p: Anſ. He inſpired holy men, and made them write it 1 Tim. 3, 16.

head.hi: Q. But why would God haue his Word written?

div.p: Anſ. Firſt that all men might the more eaſily know it Rom 15, 4 Ioh. 20, 31. Againe that it might endure to all ages Deut. 29, 29.

head.hi: Q. To whom, and for whom did they write it?

div.p: Anſ. Not to the preſent times or perſons onely, but for the perpetuall vſe, inſtruction, and direction of the Church for euer Rom. 15, 4 Deut. 29, 29.

argument.p: Of the knowledge of God out of his Word.

head.hi: Q. VVHat is reuealed of God in the Scriptures?

div.p:
Anſ. Two things, the one touching
God himſelfe, the other touching his ſeruice and worſhip.

head.hi: Q. What is then reuealed to vs, touching God himſelfe?

div.p: Anſw. Theſe points. 1. That there is but one true God Deut. 6, 4 1 Cor. 8, 5, 6. 2 That there be thrée perſons in Trinitie, yet but one God 1 Iohn 5, 7. 3. That this God is Infinite, Inuiſible, Omnipotent, moſt Wiſe, Iuſt, Mercifull, and Holy Exod. 34, 50 1 Sam. 2, 2. 1 Tim. 1, 17 Rom. 16, 26, 27.

head.hi: Q. What be theſe three perſons called in the Scriptures?

div.p: Anſ. The Father, the Word, or Sonne, and the holy Ghoſt 1 Ioh. 5, 7.

head.hi: Q. How can there be three Perſons, and yet but one God?

div.p: Anſ. We cannot comprehend it by reaſon, but we muſt beléeue it by Faith, ſéeing Gods Word ſaith ſo 1 Tim. 3, 16.

head.hi: Q. How is the Trinity of perſons reuealed in the Scriptures?

div.p: Anſ. It was intimated, and ſhadowed in the Old Teſtament Gen. 1, 26 & 19 24 Pſal. 110, 1 Prou. 30, 4, but is plainely taught and affirmed in the New 1 Ioh. 5, 7 2 Cor. 13, 14 1 Pet. 1, 2.

head.hi: Q. Why was it not made plaine,
till then?

div.p: Anſ. Becauſe then God was manifeſted in the fleſh Ioh. 1, 14.

argument.p: Of Gods worſhip, and the kindes of it.

head.hi: Q. VVHat is reuealed in the Scriptures, touching Gods worſhip?

div.p: Anſ. The matter and the manner of it.

head.hi: Q. What is there taught vs touching the matter of Gods worſhip?

div.p: A. Thrée things, the kindes, the degrées and the duties of it.

head.hi: Q. What be the kindes of Gods worſhip?

div.p: A. Two, Internall and Externall 1 Cor. 6, 20.

head.hi: Q. What is the Internall worſhip of God?

div.p: A. That which is performed by the Inner man: the ſoule, ſpirit and affections Prou. 2, 26.

head.hi: Q. And what is 〈…〉 ?

div.p: A. That worſhip 〈…〉 which is performed with the 〈…〉 parts of it Rom. 12, 1▪ 1 Cor. 6, 13, being the outward man.

head.hi: Q. What be the degrees of Gods worſhip?

div.p: A. Thrée: publike, priuate and perſonall.

head.hi: Q. What is the publike worſhip of God?

div.p: A. That which is performed, in, and by the publike congregation Pſal. 26, 22, & 40, 9, 10, and 122, 1..

head.hi: Q. What is the priuate?

div.p: Anſ. That which is performed in our houſes and families Gen. 18, 19. Ioſh. 24, 15.

head.hi: Q. And what is the perſonall?

div.p: A. That which euery Chriſtian man performeth by himſelfe Math. 6, 5, 6..

argument.p: Of the paerts and duties of Gods worſhip.

head.hi: Q. VVHat be the parts or duties of Gods publike worſhip?

div.p:
Anſ. To meete together duely
with •••• ation, in time and place 〈…〉
▪ And there, Firſt n Pſal. 122, 1 and chiefly to call on God by prayer and thankſgiuing Nehem. 8, 1. to the 8.. Secondly, to heare Gods words read and preached Acts 20, 7 Thirdly, to partake in the Holy Sacraments q.
Ezra 9, 1, 4 pſal. 95, 1

head.hi: Q. And what bee the duties of Gods priuate worſhip in the family?

div.p: A. For the family daily to méete together Ioſh. 24, 15. And firſt to call on God by prayer and thankeſgiuing 1 Tim. 2, 8. Secondly, to read Gods word Deut. 6, 6, 7. Thirdly, to inſtruct one another in Religion Gen. 18, 19 Deut. 6, 7. Fourthly, to call to minde what was taught in the Church, and apply it to themſelues Acts 17, 11.

head.hi: Q. To whom belongs this duty?

div.p: A. To the chiefe in the family, or elſe he is to appoint one fit to doe it Deut. 6, 6 Gen. 18 19.

head.hi: Q. And what is the perſonall worſhip that euery one is to performe by himſelfe?

div.p:
A. To retire himſelfe euery day into ſecret, and there betwixt God and himſelfe Math. 6, 6. Firſt, to lay open
his heart, and confeſſe his ſinnes Secondly, to call on God, and giue him thankes for his mercies Pſal. 50, 14, 15. Thirdly, to reade Gods Word Pſal. 119, 11, 24, 24. Fourthly, to call to minde what was preached, and make vſe of it to himſelfe Deut. 6, 5, & 10, 12, 20 2 Chron. 13, 18, & 20, 20..

head.hi: Q. But what is the internall worſhip of God?

div.p: Anſ. To honour him with all our hearts; to loue, feare and truſt in him aboue all, and to beléeue his Word Ioh. 4, 24..

head.hi: Q. In what manner is God to bee worſhipped?

div.p: A. In ſpirit and truth: ſpiritually, that is, with our hearts and ſoules, as well as our bodies, and truly, that is, ſincerely, and heartily, without hypocriſie Pſal. 32, 2..

argument.p: Of Gods workes, and the Creation.

head.hi: Q, VVHat bee the workes of God, by which hee hath
eſpecially made knowne himſelfe?

div.p: A. Foure: Creation, Gubernation, Redemption, and Sanctification.

head.hi: Q. How are theſe the workes of God?

div.p: A. Thus. God created all things by his power, Gouernes them all by his wiſedome and prouidence, Redéemes mankinde in his loue and mercie, and ſanctifies them hee redéemes, by his grace and holineſſe.

head.hi: Q. What is the worke of Creation?

div.p: A. A worke of Gods power, by which he made the world, and all things in it, viſible, and inuiſible Gen. 1. Coloſſ. 1, 16.

head.hi: Q. When did he create it?

div.p: A. In the beginning, when hee knew it good Gen. 1, 1.

head.hi: Q. Whereof did he create it?

div.p: Anſ. Of nothing, to ſhew his might and power Heb. 11, 3.

head.hi: Q. With what inſtruments made he it?

div.p: A. With none, but onely by his Will and Word Gen. 1, often Pſal. 24 8, 5.

head.hi: Q. In what time made hee the world?

div.p: A. In ſixe dayes, that we might more particularly conſider of the creatures Gen. 1, & 2.

head.hi: Q. In what order made he them?

div.p: A. The meaneſt firſt, and better and better euery day Gen. 1, all ouer. .

head.hi: Q. When made he man?

div.p: Anſ. Laſt of all, becauſe hee was Lord of all, and might find all things ready for him Cen. 1, 26.

argument.p: Of the worke of Gubernation.

head.hi: Q. VVHat is the worke of Gubernation?

div.p: A. A worke of Gods prouidence, by which he maintains and gouerns all things created Pſal. 104, 29, 30 Nehem. 9, 6..

head.hi: Q. What neede is there of the worke of Gubernation?

div.p:
A. Becauſe as the world had neuer bin, if God had not made it, ſo it
would not continue, if he did not vphold it Pſal. 104, 29 Acts 17, 28 Pſal. 119, 90, 91..

head.hi: Q. But if God gouerne all things, how then came ſinne and miſchiefe into the world?

div.p: A. Through the diuels malice, and mans weakeneſſe Eccleſ. 7, 29.

head.hi: Q. But why then ſuffers hee it in the world?

div.p: A. Becauſe hee knowes how to make good vſe of it, as a good Phyſicion can make of the vildeſt poyſan Exod. 9, 16. Pſal. 76. 10..

head.hi: Q. Againe, if God gouerne the world, how comes it to paſſe, that euill men proſper, that be Gods enemies?

div.p: A. Becauſe they be men of this world, and chuſe to haue their portion in this life Pſal. 17, 14.

head.hi: Q. And why are good men vexed and afflicted?

div.p:
A. For thrée cauſes. Firſt, becauſe they bee Gods deare children, and néede chaſtiſement Heb. 12, 5, 6, 7, &c. . Secondly, they haue many ill humours in them, that are to be purged and corrected Pſal. 139, 23. 24.. Thirdly, Againe, their
portions are reſerued for a better life Luke 16, 15.

argument.p: Of ſin, and the neceſsity of the worke of Redemption.

head.hi: Q. VVHat is the worke of Redemption?

div.p: A. A worke of Gods mercie, by which he recouers and ſaues a portion of mankinde Lam. 3, 22.

head.hi: Q. What need had mankinde to be redeemed?

div.p: A. Becauſe man by ſin had loſt himſelfe Hoſ. 13, 9.

head.hi: Q. What is ſinne?

div.p: A. Sinne is the breach of Gods Law 1 Ioh. 3, 4.

head.hi: Q. What are the kindes of ſinne?

div.p: A. Two, Originall and Actuall.

head.hi: Q. How doe theſe differ?

div.p: A. Originall ſinne, is the ſinne of our nature, Actuall, the ſinne of our liues.

head.hi: Q. What is Originall ſinne?

div.p:
A. A depriuation our nature
in all the parts and faculties, whereby we are prone to all euill, and vnfit for all good Pſal. 51, 5 Gen. 6, 5..

head.hi: Q. What is actuall ſinne?

div.p: A. The breach of Gods Law in our thoughts, words and déeds Pſal. 19, 12.

head.hi: Q. What be the kindes of actuall ſinne?

div.p: Anſ. Two: Commiſſions, and Omiſſions.

head.hi: Q. What is the ſinne of Commiſſion?

div.p: A. By which we doe in thought, word, or déed, that we ought not.

head.hi: Q. And what is the ſin of Omiſſion?

div.p: A. By which we faile in thought, word, or déed, that we ought not to doe.

head.hi: Q. What is the reward of ſinne?

div.p: A. The wrath of God, and all the curſes of the Law Deut. 27, 26 Rom. 6, 23.

argument.p: Of the Law of God.

head.hi: Q. HOw know we ſin to be ſin?

div.p:
Anſ. By the Law comes
the knowledge of ſinne Rom. 3, 20 and 7, 7..

head.hi: Q. What is the Law?

div.p: A. The couenant of workes betwixt God and man Ierom. 31, 32.

head.hi: Q. How be Gods Lawes diſtinguiſhed?

div.p: A. Gods Lawes are either Ceremoniall, Iudiciall, or Morall.

head.hi: Q. How differ theſe Lawes?

div.p: A. Thus. Ceremoniall and Iudiciall belonged to the Iewes alone, the Morall to them and vs, and all mankinde.

head.hi: Q. How did they belong to the Iewes?

div.p: A. Thus. The Ceremoniall belonged to the ordering of their Church, the Iudiciall, to the gouerning of their common wealth Rom. 9, 4.

head.hi: Q. What is the Morall Law?

div.p: A. The declaration of Gods perfect Iuſtice, as the Goſpell is the Reuelation of his mercie.

head.hi: Q. What doth the Morall Law containe?

div.p:
A. Perfect righteouſneſſe, that is, a commanding of all goodneſſe,
and a prohibition of all euill.

argument.p: Of the firſt Table, and firſt Commandement.

head.hi: Q. HOw is the Law diuided?

div.p: A. Into two tables, the one contayning foure Commandements, the other ſixe.

head.hi: Q. Why into two, and no more?

div.p: A. Becauſe all righteouſneſſe is reduced to two heads, namely towards God, or towards man Math. 22, 39, 40..

head.hi: Q. What doth the firſt Table containe?

div.p: A. Perfect righteouſneſſe, and all holy duties, touching God and his worſhip.

head.hi: Q. Which is the firſt Commandement?

div.p: A. This, thou ſhalt haue no other Gods before me Exod. 10, 3..

head.hi: Q. What is the ſubſtance of the firſt Commandement?

div.p: A. The choice and inward worſhip of the true God.

head.hi: Q. What is the affirmatiue part of the firſt Commandement?

div.p: A. Chuſe and worſhip the true God for thy God.

head.hi: Q. What is the negatiue part of this Commandement?

div.p: A. Account not that to be God, which by nature is not God.

argument.p: Of the ſecond, third, and fourth Commandements.

head.hi: Q. VVHat is the ſecond Commandement?

div.p: A. Thou ſhalt not make vnto thée any grauen image Exod. 20, 4.

head.hi: Q. What is the ſubſtance of this Commandement?

div.p: A. The ſacred and ſolemne worſhip of the true God.

head.hi: Q. What is the affirmatiue part of it?

div.p: A. Thou ſhalt worſhip the true God as he hath commanded.

head.hi: Q. What is the negatiue part of this Commandement?

div.p: A. Thou ſhalt neither worſhip a falſe god, nor the true God falſly.

head.hi: Q. What is the third Commandement?

div.p: A. Thou ſhalt not take the Name of the Lord thy God in vaine, &c Exod. 20, 7.

head.hi: Q. What is the ſubſtance of this third Commandement?

div.p: A. The magnifying and glorifying of the true God in all things.

head.hi: Q. What is the negatiue part of this Commandement?

div.p: A. Thou ſhalt not bereaue God of his honour due vnto him.

head.hi: Q. What is the affirmatiue part of it?

div.p: A. In all things giue God his glory 1 Cor, 10, 31..

head.hi: Q. What is the fourth Commandement?

div.p: A. Remember that thou kéepe holy the Sabbath day Exod. 20, 8, 9, &c. .

head.hi: Q. What is the ſubſtance of this Commandement?

div.p: A. It ſets downe the time allotted, and conſecrated to the worſhip and glorifying of God.

head.hi: Q. What is the affirmatiue part of this Commandement?

div.p: A. Keepe holy the Sabbath day of the Lord.

head.hi: Q. What is the negatiue part of it?

div.p: A. Pollute not the Sabbath of the Lord.

argument.p: Of the ſecond Table.

head.hi: Q. VVHat doth the ſecond Table containe?

div.p: A. True loue, and perfect righteouſneſſe towards our neighbour.

head.hi: Q. How is it diuided?

div.p: A. Into ſixe Commandements, which containe all duties of man to man.

head.hi: Q. What is the firſt Commandement?

div.p: A. Honour thy father and mother, &c Exod. 20, 12.

head.hi: Q. What is the ſubſtance of the fift Commandement?

div.p:
Anſ. The preſeruation of our neighbours honour and excellencie
with our owne.

head.hi: Q. What is the affirmatiue part of it?

div.p: A. Preſerue by all meanes the dignity of thy neighbours perſons.

head.hi: Q. But who is our neighbour in this caſe?

div.p: A. All men, whether Superiors, Equals, or Inferiors Luke 10, 29 30.

head.hi: Q. What is the negatiue part of this Commandement?

div.p: A. Debaſe not thy neighbour.

head.hi: Q. What is the ſixt Commandement?

div.p: A. Thou ſhalt not kill Exod. 20 13.

head.hi: Q. What is the ſubſtance of this Commandement?

div.p: Anſ. The preſeruation of our owne, and our neighbours life and health.

head.hi: Q. What is the negatiue part of this negatiue Commandement?

div.p: Anſw. Doe not hurt, nor hinder thine owne, nor thy neighbours life nor health.

head.hi: Q. What is the affirmatiue part of it?

div.p: A. Preſerue thy owne and thy neighbours life and health.

argument.p: Of the ſeuenth, eight, and ninth Commandements.

head.hi: Q. VVHat is the ſeuenth Commandement?

div.p: Anſ. Thou ſhalt not commit Adultrie Exod. 20, 14..

head.hi: Q. What is the ſubſtance of this Commandement?

div.p: Anſ. The preſeruation of our neighbours chaſtitie and our owne.

head.hi: Q. What is the negatiue part of this negatiue Commandement?

div.p: Anſ. Thou ſhalt not hurt, nor hinder thy neighbours chaſtity nor thy owne.

head.hi: Queſt. What is the affirmatiue part of it?

div.p: Anſ. Preſerue thy neighbours chaſtitie and thine owne.

head.hi: Q. What is the eighth Commandement?

div.p: A. Thou ſhalt not ſteale Exod. 20, 15.

head.hi: Q. What is the ſubſtance of this Commandement?

div.p: Anſ. The preſeruation of our neighbours eſtate and our owne, and the maintenance of Iuſtice in all dealing.

head.hi: Q. What is the negatiue part of this negatiue Commandement?

div.p: A. Thou ſhalt not hurt nor hinder thy neighbours goods.

head.hi: Q. What is the affirmatiue part of it?

div.p: Anſ. Thou ſhalt preſerue and helpe to increaſe thy neighbours goods.

head.hi: Q. What is the ninth Commandement?

div.p: Anſ. Thou ſhalt not beare falſe witneſſe, &c Exod. 20, 16..

head.hi: Q. What is the ſubſtance of this Commandement?

div.p: Anſ. The preſeruation of our Neighbours good name, and our owne.

head.hi: Q. What is the negatiue part of this Commandement?

div.p: A. Hurt not thy neighbours good name, nor thy owne.

head.hi: Q. What is the affirmatiue part of it?

div.p: A. Preſerue thy neighbours good name, and thy owne.

argument.p: Of the laſt Commandement, and the vſe of the whole Law.

head.hi: Q. VVHat is the laſt Commandement?

div.p: A. Thou ſhalt not couet thy neighbours houſe, &c Exod. 20, 17.

head.hi: Q. What is the ſubſtance of this Commandement?

div.p: Anſw. The rectifying of our thoughts, as the other were for ordering our conſents, wordes and déeds.

head.hi: Q. What is the negatiue part of this negatiue Commandement?

div.p:
Anſw. Thou ſhalt not hurt thy
neighbour, no not in thought.

head.hi: Q. What is the affirmatiue part of it?

div.p: Anſ. Wiſh and deſire thy neighbours good in all things.

head.hi: Q. In which of the Commandements is originall ſinne forbidden?

div.p: A. In the whole Law, but moſt properly in the tenth Rom, 7, 7..

head.hi: Q▪ What doth the Law beſtow on the keepers of it?

div.p: A. Iuſtification, life eternall, and all happineſſe Leuit. 18, 5 Ezek. 20, 11. Kom. 2, 13.

head.hi: Queſt. How is the Law to bee kept?

div.p: Anſ. Perfectly in thought, word and déed, with all our heart, and all our ſoule d Rom. 7, 14. Luke 10, 27.

head.hi: Q. Who was euer able to keepe the Law thus?

div.p: Anſ. Adam in his innocencie before he fell Eccleſ. 7, 29..

argument.p: How the Law doth driue vs to Chriſt.

head.hi: Q. VVHat doth the Law lay vpon the breakers of it?

div.p: A. Eternall death Rom. 6, 23, and as Harbongers to it, all infirmities, ſickneſſes, plagues, and curſes on body, goods, name, ſtate and ſoule, that Gods Iuſtice can inflict Deut. 28, 15 16, &c. .

head.hi: Q. Who hath broke the Law in this manner?

div.p:
A. All men that came of Adam
Rom. 3, 23 and 5, 19..

head.hi: Q. What ſhall then become of all mankinde?

div.p: A. The Law findes them vnder ſinne, and therefore leaues them ſubiect to damnation Rom. 3, 20, & 23.

head.hi: Q. Is there then no hope of the ſaluation of mankinde?

div.p: Anſ. None at all in the Iuſtice of GOD, but in his mercy there is hope Lam. 3, 22.

head.hi: Q. Where hath God manifeſted
that mercie?

div.p: A. In the Goſpell Rom. 1, 15, 16 1 Ioh. 4, 9..

head.hi: Q. What is the Goſpell?

div.p: A. It is the couenant of Grace, betwixt God and man Rom, 1, 16.

head.hi: Q. How hath God reuealed his Mercie in the Goſpell, or Couenant of Grace?

div.p: Anſ. By allowing mankinde a Suretie and Sauiour, euen Ieſus Chriſt, to whom we muſt flie to eſcape the curſe of the Law, and thus the Law is a School-maſter, to driue vs to Chriſt Gal. 3, 24..
div.q: And thus wee ſee the neceſſitie of our Redemption, cauſed by our ſinnes and the Law: Let vs now be inſtructed touching the Author and the meanes of our Redemption.

argument.p: Of Chriſt Ieſus the Redeemer.

head.hi: Q. VVHo is the Redeemer of mankinde?

div.p: A. The ſecond perſon in Trinity, now called by God his Father, Ieſus Chriſt 1 Ioh. 2, 1, 2 1 Tim. 1, 15.

head.hi: Q. To whom is he a Redeemer?

div.p: A. Onely to mankinde, and to as many of them, as God elected to ſaluation Heb. 2, 19.

head.hi: Q. Who was this Ieſus Chriſt?

div.p: A. The Sonne of God, and the Sonne of man Rom. 1, 3..

head.hi: Q. Why muſt the Redeemer bee Man?

div.p: Anſ. Becauſe elſe he could not ſuffer 1 Pet. 3, 18.

head.hi: Q. And why muſt he needes bee GOD?

div.p: Anſ. Becauſe elſe he could not ſatiſfie 2 Cor. 5, 19.

head.hi: Q. But why ſhould Gods Sonne be the Redeemer, might there not haue beene ſome other?

div.p: Anſ. No, for no man could ſaue himſelfe, much-leſſe could he ſaue another, and no creature elſe could, becauſe none but Chriſt could both ſuffer and ſatiſfie Acts 4, 12.

argument.p: Of Faith, and of the Creede.

head.hi: Q. HOw doe we know all this to be true?

div.p: A. By the Goſpell, which brings the good newes of this Redéemer Luke 2, 10..

head.hi: Q. How doe we know the Goſpell to be true?

div.p: A. By Faith Rom. 1, 17..

head.hi: Q. What is Faith?

div.p: Anſ. A guift of God by which a man beleeues Gods word to bée true Heb. 11, 1.

head.hi: Q. What are the things a Chriſtian man ought by his Faith to beleeue for ſaluation?

div.p: Anſ. They bée contained in the Créede.

head.hi: Q. Which is the Creede?

div.p: Anſ. I beléeue in God the Father Almighty, &c.

head.hi: Q. What are the principle points contained in the Creede?

div.p: Anſ. Foure.

list.item:
The
1. Touching God the Father our Creator.
2. God the Sonne, our Redéemer.
3. The holy Ghoſt our Sanctifier.
4. Concerning Gods Church.

head.hi: Q. What is laide downe concerning God the Father?

div.p: A. That hee is God Almighty who made & maintaines all things Acts 17. 24.

head.hi: Q. What is to bee beleeued touching the ſecond perſon?

div.p: Anſ. Two things, one that he wrought out our ſaluation: the other ye he wil giue vs poſſeſſion of it.

head.hi: Queſt. How did Chriſt worke out our ſaluation?

div.p: A. By this order, & theſe degrées.

list.item: 1. He was incarnate for vs Ioh. 1, 14 Rom. 1, 3..
2. He ſuffred, died, and was buried 1 Cor. 15, 3.
3. He roſe againe from death Rom. 4, 25 1 Cor. 15, 4.
4. He aſcended into heauen 1 Pet. 3, 22. Acts 2, 9.
5. He ſits at Gods right hand and makes interceſſion for vs Heb, 11, 12 & 9, 2, 3. and 7, 25..

head.hi: Q. And when will he giue vs poſſeſſion of glory and ſaluation?

div.p: Anſ. When he comes againe to Iudgement Acts 10, 42.

head.hi: Q. What is to bee beleeued touching the Holy-Ghoſt?

div.p: Anſ. That he is true God, and the ſanctifier of all holy men Acts 28, 29 with Eſay 6, 9. 1 Ioh. 5, 7 Rom. 1, 4..

head.hi: Q. What is to be beleeued touching the Church of God?

div.p: A. That it is holy 1 Cor. 1, 2. Epheſ. 5, 27 and Catholicke, Mat. 28, 19 Rom. 3, 29. that it is vniuerſall ouer all the world, and that great priuiledges belong to it.

head.hi: Q. What be theſe priuiledges?

div.p: A. Theſe foure.

list.item: Firſt, Communion of Saints Heb. 10, 25.
Secondly, Forgiueneſſe of ſinnes Act. 26, 16.
Thirdly, Reſurrection of our bodies Acts 26, 8. Rom. 6, 8. and 8 11 1 Cor. 15..
Fourthly, Life euerlaſting Math. 25, 46.

argument.p: Of particular, and ſauing faith, and how it is wrought.

head.hi: Q. IS this faith ſufficient for ſaluation?

div.p: Anſ. No, but we muſt apply all this to our ſelues Gal. 2, 20.

head.hi: Q. How may we doe that?

div.p: Anſ. By a ſpeciall ſauing and iuſtifying faith Rom. 5, 2..

head.hi: Q. What is that Faith more then the former?

div.p: Anſ. A ſpeciall grace of God in the ſoule, by which a man beléeues his owne reconciliation with God, and ſaluation by Chriſt Iob 19, 25. 2 Tim. 1, 12.

head.hi: Q. How doth God worke this Faith in men?

div.p: Anſ. By preaching the Word, and by his holy Sacraments, which are his owne Ordinances Rom. 10, 14, Acts 13, 46..

head.hi: Q. How differ theſe two?

div.p: A. Thus, the Word containes the couenant of God: and the Sacraments are ſeales, confirming the couenant Rom. 5, 11.

head.hi: Queſt. Who are to preach the Word, and to adminiſter the Sacrament?

div.p: A. Our Paſtors and Teachers, who are therefore called Gods Miniſters and ours 2 Cor. 5, 18, 19.

head.hi: Q. And what muſt wee doe our ſelues?

div.p: Anſ. Firſt, diligently frequent the Congregations. Secondly, pray for a bleſſing on Gods Ordinances Acts 13, 44. Rom. 15, 30 Epheſ. 6, 18, 19 Theſ. 5, 25.

argument.p: Of the Sacraments, and of Baptiſme.

head.hi: Q. VVHat be the Sacraments?

div.p: A. Outward viſible ſignes, euidences, and aſſurances of inward and inuiſible bleſſings Rom. 4, 11..

head.hi: Q. Who ordained the Sacraments?

div.p: A. Onely God: for they be parts of his worſhip, and ſeales of his Couenants Gen. 17 Exod. 11..

head.hi: Q. How many Sacraments bee there in the New Teſtament?

div.p: Anſ. Two, Baptiſme, and the Lords Supper, which ſuccéed Circumciſion, and the Paſſeouer in the Old Teſtament Math. 28. 1 Cor. 12..

head.hi: Q. What are the eſſentiall parts of euery Sacrament?

div.p: Anſ. Two, the one outward and viſible, the other inward and inuiſible repreſented thereby 1 Pet. 3, 21.

head.hi: Q. What is the Sacrament of Baptiſme?

div.p: Anſ. The Sacrament of our admiſſion & entrance into the Church and houſhold of God Gen. 27. Acts 2, 38..

head.hi: Q. What is the outward thing in it?

div.p: A. Water, and the waſhing of the body in water Math. 3, 16.

head.hi: Q. And what is the inward and ſpirituall bleſſing?

div.p: A. The waſhing of the ſoule, in the blood of Ieſus Chriſt 1 Pet. 3, 21, Ioh. 1, 33..

head.hi: Q. Who are capable of this Sacrament?

div.p: A. Beleeuers and the children of beleeuers Acts 8, 36 37..

head.hi: Q. Is this Sacrament neceſſarie to ſaluation?

div.p: A. Yes, to all that can aske and take it Iohn 1, 5.

argument.p: Of the Sacrament of the Lords Supper.

head.hi: Q. VVHat is the Sacrament of the Lords Supper?

div.p: A. The Sacrament of our communion and fellowſhip with Chriſt, and with God by Chriſt 1 Cor. 10, 16. 1 Iohn 1, 3.

head.hi: Q. Why is it called the Lords Supper?

div.p: A. Becauſe Chriſt ordained it at his laſt Supper Math. 26, 26..

head.hi: Q. Why is this Sacrament often adminiſtred, and Baptiſme but once?

div.p: A. Becauſe it ſufficeth to bee once borne, but we muſt often bee fed Ioh. 1, 3 Ioh. 6, 36 Iohn 4, 15.

head.hi: Q. When is one old enough to receiue?

div.p: A. When they haue knowledge and deuotion 1 Cor. 11, 28.

head.hi: Q. What is the outward thing in this Sacrament?

div.p: A. To eate and drink Bread and Wine, ſet apart for that vſe 1 Cor. 11, 23.

head.hi: Q. What is the inward and ſpirituall?

div.p: A. To féed on Chriſt by Faith and Loue 1 Cor. 11, 24 Iohn 6, 35, 36 &c. .

head.hi: Q. What muſt we doe before we receiue?

div.p: A. Bee reconciled to God by repentance, and to our neighbours by charity 1 Cor. 11, 28.

head.hi: Q. What geſture is fitteſt to receiue in?

div.p: A. That which is moſt humble, becauſe then wee ſhew the Lords death 1 Cor. 11, 26 Math. 5, 23..

head.hi: Q. What muſt we doe when we haue receiued?

div.p: A. Not drinke and play, but as at all times, ſo that day eſpetially we ought to practiſe holineſſe and ſanctification Leuit. 11, 44 Exod. 12, 8, & 13, 6, 7. 1 Pet. 1, 14, 15..

head.hi: Q. What needs that, ſeeing wee are iuſtified by Chriſt?

div.p: Anſ. Wée cannot be ſaued vnleſſe we bee ſanctified as well as iuſtified 2 Cor. 7, 1. 1 Ioh. 3, 3. 1 Cor. 6, 11..

argument.p: Of the worke of ſanctification.

head.hi: Q. WHat is the worke of ſanctification?

div.p: Anſw. A worke of the Holy Ghoſt, by which ſuch as are redéemed, are made new creatures, and enabled to doe good and Holy workes 1 Theſſ. 4, 3..

head.hi: Q. How doth the Holy Ghoſt ſanctifie vs?

div.p:
Anſ. By his owne worke and bleſſing on the word of God and
Sacraments Ioh. 15, 3. Pſal. 119, 9..

head.hi: Q. What be the parts of ſanctification?

div.p: A. Two: Mortification and Vinification Rom. 6, 11.

head.hi: Queſtion. What is Mortification?

div.p: Anſ. The killing of our corruption, and weakening of ſinne in vs Rom. 6, 6.

head.hi: Queſtion. And what is Vinification?

div.p: A. The quickening vp of grace and holineſſe in our ſoules Rom. 6, 4. Pſal. 119, 37..

head.hi: Queſt. How are theſe wrought in vs?

div.p: Anſ. By the vertue of Chriſt his death, and reſurrection applyed vnto vs in the Word and Sacraments Rom. 6, 4, 5. Pſal. 119, 50..

argument.p: Of Repentance, and good workes, the fruites of Sanctification.

head.hi: Q. VVHat be the fruites of Sanctification?

div.p: A. Two, Repentance and good workes Math. 3, 8. Acts 26, 20..

head.hi: Q. What is Repentance?

div.p: Anſ. A heartie ſorrow for our ſinnes, ioyned with amendement of life 2 Cor. 7, 9 10 Acts 2, 38, 26 20.

head.hi: Q. When is it good to repent?

div.p: Anſ. Repentance is neuer too late, but that is beſt that is betimes Eccleſ. 12, 1 1 Kings 18, 12..

head.hi: Q. Where is Repentance commanded?

div.p: Anſ. Not in the Law, but in the Goſpel Deut. 27, 26, Math. 3, 2, and 4, 17.

head.hi: Q. What be good workes?

div.p:
Anſ. Such as God hath commanded vs to doe, or promiſed a
bleſſing if we doe them Eſay 1, 12 Micah 6, 8 Eſay 56, 1, 2..

head.hi: Q. How muſt a good Worke be done?

div.p: Anſ. With two conditions.

list.item: Firſt, with Faith in Chriſt Rom. 14, 23.
Secondly, in obedience to Gods will Epheſ. 6, 5, 6, 7..

argument.p: Of the workes of Piety, and of Prayer.

head.hi: Q. WHat be the kindes of good workes?

div.p: A. Thrée.

list.item:
Workes
of Piety towards God.
of Charity towards the poore.
of Iuſtice towardes all men.

head.hi: Q. What be the workes of Pietie?

div.p:
Anſ. The duties of Gods worſhip, which are commanded in the
firſt Table, a chiefe whereof is prayer.

head.hi: Q. Why doe you call Prayer, a chiefe worke of Pietie?

div.p: A. For two cauſes. Firſt, Prayer ſanctifies all the reſt Tim. 4, 45.: againe, the reſt are but ſometimes to bee done, but prayer continually 1 Theſſ. 5, 17.

head.hi: Q. How can wee alwayes pray, ſeeing wee muſt worke in our callings?

div.p: Anſ. Wee may alwayes lift vp our hearts to God, and that is the chiefe thing in prayer Exod. 14, 15 Rom. 8, 26 Pſal. 119, 58..

head.hi: Q. What be the parts of Prayer?

div.p: A. Two: Petition and thankſgiuing Pſal. 50, 15..

head.hi: Q. What is Petition?

div.p: A. When we aſke of God any good thing, or the remouing of any euill Eſay 26, 16 Math. 7, 7.

head.hi: Q. What is thankſgiuing?

div.p: A. When we giue God thankes for receiuing of any good, or remoouing any euill Pſal. 30, 11 12, and 116▪ 12 and 116, 12, 13..

argument.p: Of the Circumſtances of Prayer.

head.hi: Q. VVHo is bound to pray?

div.p: Anſ. Euery one, for euery one hath néede 1 Tim. 2, 8 Rom. 3, 23.

head.hi: Queſt. To whom are wee to pray?

div.p: Anſ. Onely to God: for he can onely helpe Pſal. 50, 15 Rom. 10, 14..

head.hi: Queſt. In whoſe name are wee to pray?

div.p: Anſ. Onely in the name and mediation of Ieſus Chriſt the Son of God Ioh▪ 14, 13, 14 1 Tim. 2, 5.

head.hi: Q. Where are wee to pray?

div.p: Anſ. In euery place, for God is preſent euery where 1 Tim. 2, 8.

head.hi: Q. When are we to pray?

div.p: A. In publike when the congregation méetes, in priuate on all occaſions, eſpetially at morning, at euening and at meate Lam. 3, 41. Pſal. 119, 164. Pſal. 55, 17.

head.hi: Queſt. In what tongue may wee pray?

div.p: Anſ. In any we vnderſtand, elſe in none 1 Cor. 14, 15 &c. .

head.hi: Queſt. In what ieſture are we to pray?

div.p: Anſ. In the humbleſt, becauſe we are petitioners Micah 6, 8 1 Kings 8, 22 54.

head.hi: Q. For whom are we to pray?

div.p: Anſ. For our ſelues and all men, euen our enemies 1 Tim. 2, 1 Eſay 53, 12 Math 5, 44.

head.hi: Q. With whom may we pray?

div.p: Anſ. With any, who pray to the true God in the name of Ieſus Chriſt 1 Cor. 1, 2.

argument.p: Of the Lords Prayer.

head.hi: Q. HAue we any direction or patterne for our prayers?

div.p: A. Yes, the beſt that can be, one of Chriſts owne making, called therefore the Lords prayer, Our Father, &c Math 6, 9. Luke 11, 2..

head.hi: Q. What is contained in the Lords Prayer?

div.p: A. Thrée things.

list.item:
A
Preamble.
Prayer.
Confirmation of all.

head.hi: Q. Which is the Preamble?

div.p: Anſ. This. Our Father which art in Heauen.

head.hi: Queſt. What containes the Preamble?

div.p: Anſ. A deſcription of God our Father, to whom we ought to pray.

head.hi: Q. And how is hee there deſcribed?

div.p: Anſ. By two things, the firſt ſhewes his willingneſſe to heare vs, for he is Our Father: the latter, his ability to helpe vs, for He is in Heauen, and hath it at his command Eſay 49, 15 Pſal 115, 3.

head.hi: Q. But if God be euery-where, how is he ſaid to be in Heauen?

div.p: A. Not that hee is contained or included there: for He fils Heauen and earth. But that his Maieſtie, Power and Glory, ſhines and appeares there eſpecially 1 Kings 8, 27 Eſay 66, 1.

argument.p: Of the Petitions in the Lords Prayer.

head.hi: Q. VVHat is contained in the prayer?

div.p: A. Two things, Petitions and Thankeſgiuing.

head.hi: Q. What be the Petitions?

div.p: A. Sixe in all, and they bee of two ſorts.
Some concerning God.
The reſt our ſelues.

head.hi: Q. Which be they that concerne God?

div.p: A. Thrée. The firſt wiſheth that his Name may be hallowed, that is, honoured and vſed reuerently Deut. 28. 58.
The ſecond, that his Kingdome and Goſpell may be aduanced Pſal. 67, 2, 3.
The third, that his will may be fulfilled of vs and all creatures Math. 26, 39..

head.hi: Q. And what are they that concerne our ſelues?

div.p: A. Thrée more. The firſt aſkes all things needfull for this life, vnder one moſt principall, namely Bread Pſal. 104. 15. Ezek. 4, 16 Leuit. 26, 26..
The ſecond prayes for forgiueneſſe of our ſins, conditionally, as we forgiue others Dan. 9, 18, 19 Math. 6, 14 Marke 11, 25.
The third prayes for Deliuerance from the diuell, and the daunger of temptation Pſal. 91, 14 Reuel. 3, 10, 15.

head.hi: Q. And what is the Thankeſgiuing?

div.p: Anſ. In theſe words, where wee acknowledge the Kingdome, Power and Glory, belong to God for euer and euer 1 Chron. 29 10, 11, 12, &c. Neh. 9, 5, 6, &c .

head.hi: Q. And what is the ſeale or confirmation of this prayer?

div.p: A. The word AMEN, whereby our Faith ſubſcribes and ſaith, So be it Lord, or it ſhall be ſo 1 Cor. 14, 16.

head.hi: Queſt. Is it lawfull to ſay this prayer?

div.p:
A. Yes, for ſo ſaith Saint Luke, when you pray, ſay, Our Father, &c
Luke 11, 2..

head.hi: Q. And is it lawfull to make other prayers like to it?

div.p:
A. Yes, for ſo ſaith Saint Matthew,
after this manner therefore pray you Math. 6, 9..

argument.p: Of workes of Mercie, or Charitie.

head.hi: Q. ARe the workes of Piety ſufficient for ſaluation?

div.p: Anſ. No, Chriſtians muſt alſo performe workes of Mercie and Iuſtice Epheſ. 2, 10 Math. 25, 35, 35.

head.hi: Queſt. Where be they commaunded?

div.p: Anſ. In the ſecond Table of the Morall Law.

head.hi: Queſt. What be workes of Mercie or Charity?

div.p: Anſ. Such as we ought to doe to them that be poore, or in ſome diſtreſſe Math. 25, 35. Deut. 15, 7. Pſal. 41, 1..

head.hi: Queſt. How many be the workes of Mercie?

div.p: Anſ. Of two ſorts, either to the ſoules or bodies of our brethren.

head.hi: Q. What be the workes of Mercie to the ſoules of our brethren?

div.p: A. Theſe. 1. To informe and inſtruct the Ignorant Rom. 2 20..
2. To bring home him that is out of the way Iames 5. 20. Exod. 23. 4..
3. To admoniſh him that is faulty 1. Theſſ. 5. 14..
4. To encourage and confirme him that doth well Act. 14. 21. 22..
5. To comfort them that are in diſtreſſe 1. Theſſ. 5. 14..

head.hi: Q. What be the workes of Mercie towards the bodies of our brethren?

div.p: Anſ. Theſe. 1. To féede the hungry Math. 25. 35..
2. To cloathe the naked Math. 25. 36..
3. To viſit the ſicke, or the priſoners Mat. 25. 55..
4. To reléeue the oppreſſed Exod. 23 5 Pſal. 82. 4. Deut. 27. 19..
5. To bring the blind into the way Deut. 27. 18..
6. To giue and lend where néede is Math. 5. 42. Deut. 15. 7. 8. Pſal. 37. 21. 26. Ioh. 3. 17..
7. To lodge poore ſtrangers Math. 25. 35 36. Heb. 13. 2..

argument.p: Of workes of Iuſtice, or Righteouſneſſe.

head.hi: Q. VVHat bee the workes of Iuſtice?

div.p: A. Such workes of honeſty and faire dealing, as wee are bound to performe to euery man Rom. 13, 7.

head.hi: Q. When are workes of Iuſtice to be performed?

div.p: A. In the works of our callings, and in all our bargaines and dealings with men 1 Theſſ. 4, 6 Exod. 12, 49, and 23, 9..

head.hi: Q. With whom muſt wee deale iuſtly?

div.p: Anſ. With euery man, friend or foe, ſuperiour, or inferiour, good or bad, or of what religion ſoeuer he be Math. 5, 43, 44.

head.hi: Q. What be the parts of Iuſtice?

div.p: Anſ. Two. Firſt to doe right to all, wrong to none Rom. 13, 7..

Secondly, if we haue don wrong,
to make reſtitution Luke 19, 8. Exod. 21, 28, & 22, 1, &c. .

head.hi: Q. What rules doth the Holy Ghoſt giue vs for our direction in Iuſtice, and in doing right to all men?

div.p: Anſ. Theſe in the Old Teſtament.

list.item: Firſt, Thou ſhalt not ſteale, nor deale falſly, nor lie one to another Leuit. 19, 11.
Secondly, Thou ſhalt not defraud thy Neighbour, nor rob him, nor keepe his due from him Leuit. 19, 13.
Thirdly, Thou ſhalt loue thy Neighbour as thy ſelfe Leuit. 19, 18.

head.hi: Q And what rules or directions haue we in the New Teſtament?

div.p: A. Theſe. Firſt, Owe nothing to any man but loue Rom. 13, 8.
Secondly, Giue to euery one his due Rom. 13, 7..
Thirdly, Let no man defraud or goe beyond his brother in any matter 1 Theſſ. 4, 6.
Fourthly, Whatſoeuer you would that men ſhould doe to you, doe you the ſame to them Math. 7, 12.

argument.p: Of the reward of good Workes.

head.hi: Q. VVHy ſhould Chriſtians do good workes?

div.p: Anſ. For theſe cauſes.

list.item: Firſt, to obey Gods commandement, and doe his will Pſal. 119, 4.
Secondly, to honour God and his holy Religion Math 5. 1 Pet. 2, 9, 12.
Thirdly, to make ſure their own election 2 Pet. 1, 10 1 Tim. 6, 18, 19.

head.hi: Q. Is there any reward for good Workes?

div.p: Anſw. Yes, the leaſt good worke ſhall be rewarded 1 Cor. 15, 58 Math. 14, 42.

head.hi: Q. May we then merite by our good workes?

div.p: Anſw. No, but the reward is giuen in Gods mercie, through Chriſts merits Rom. 6, 23. Luke 17, 10..

head.hi: Queſt. What reward doth God giue vs by his mercifull Couenant
in Chriſt?

div.p: A. Some in this life, but more in the life to come 1 Tim. 4, 8.

head.hi: Q. What reward haue we in this life?

div.p: Anſ. Thrée, Firſt, his loue and fauour 1 Ioh. 4, 10.
Secondly, the peace and comfort of a good conſcience Rom. 14, 17.
Thirdly, all bleſſings néedfull for this life Pſal. 34, 9, and 84, 11 Math. 6, 32, 33.

head.hi: Q. And what reward in the life to come?

div.p: A. Eternall life, or euerlaſting ſaluation Math. 25, 46.

head.hi: Q. What ſhall we enioy there?

div.p: A. Perfect happineſſe, conſiſting in two things.

list.item: Firſt, a fréedome from all euill and ſinne Eſay 11, 9 Reu. 22, 9 and 21, 4..
Secondly, the fruition and enioying of all good to ſoule and body for euermore Reu. 7, 17 & 21, 22, 23..

head.hi: Q. And what is the portion of the wicked that want Faith, and feare of God, and doe no good workes?

div.p:
A. A double portion, part in this
life, and part in that to come.

head.hi: Q. What haue they in this life?

div.p: A. Gods curſe without, and an ill conſcience within Deut. 28, 15, 20, &c. and 65..

head.hi: Q. And what in the life to come?

div.p: Anſw. Euerlaſting ſeparation from God, and eternall damnation in hell with the diuell and his angels Math. 25, 41. 2 Theſſ. 1, 8, 9..

div.head: An houſhold Prayer for the Morning.
div.p:
O Thou moſt mighty Creator, Preſeruer and Sauiour of our ſoules and bodies, we heere acknowledge to thy Glory, that it is onely through thy Power and Mercie, we haue enioyed the reſt, and eſcaped the dangers of the night paſt: for, wee confeſſe wee haue deſerued, that the darkeneſſe of Death ſhould haue ſeazed on vs, and giuen vs vp into the hands of eternall darkeneſſe, becauſe wee haue ſpent our liues in the deedes of darkeneſſe: Bleſſed therefore bee
thy holy Name, for that thou haſt not delt with vs according to our deſeruings. And now we humble our ſelues before thee, and pray thée on the knees of our hearts, that as thou haſt deliuered vs from the darkeneſſe of the Night, ſo thou wouldeſt deliuer our ſoules from the ſpirituall darkeneſſe of Sinne, Error, Superſtition and Prophaneneſſe, that ſo we may neuer come within the daunger of eternall darkeneſſe: And as thou haſt reſtored to vs the light of this life, ſo good LORD vouchſafe to enlighten our hearts with the better light of thy heauenly truth, and holy Grace: that as the light of this world ſufficiently ſhewes vs our way, and directs our ſteppes and actions of the body: ſo the Spirit and Grace of Chriſt Ieſus, ſhining in our ſoules, may ſhew vs the way to walke in, leade vs in the way euerlaſting, and guide our féete in the way of peace. And
thou moſt mercifull God, who haſt giuen our bodies reſt and ſléepe, we beſéech thée in thy greater mercie, giue reſt to our ſoules, and ſweete peace vnto our conſciences this day, and all our dayes: and thou that haſt deliuered vs from the perils of the night, ſaue vs from the ſinnes of this day, and deliuer vs from the farre greater dangers, which our ſinnes may pull vpon vs.

O Lord wee goe into the world, and can hardly haue to doe with it, but the contagion of ſinne, will catch hold of vs, Lord teach vs with heauenly wiſdome, to ſée and auoide the ſame: arme vs with heauenly courage, to breake through the ſnares which ſinne and Sathan, and the wicked world ſhall lay in our way. And thou that art the God of bleſſing, vouchſafe to bleſſe vs this day in our ſoules and bodies, in the vſe of both our callings, generall as wee are Chriſtians, and members of thy Church, and perſonall, as wee are
members of this common-wealth: In our perſonall callings Lord enable vs to loue our Neighbour as our ſelues, and to doe to euery one as wee would haue them doe to vs: and giue vs a conſcionable care of ſuch duties as belong vnto vs, make vs faithfull, laborious and diligent in the diſcharge of them, yet ſuffer vs not ſo farre to be carried away with the cares of the world, and the labour of our callings, as that we ſhould neglect the duties of Pietie and godlineſſe, commaunded vnto vs in our generall calling; but teach vs gracious GOD, to ioyne the practice of theſe both together, and neuer to ſeparate them whilſt wee liue in the world, but that in the one wee may labour faithfully to ſerue our brethren, and in the other, zealouſly to ſerue and glorifie thée our God; That thus wee may with cheereful hearts, and good conſciences, ſpend our dayes, and waite for our conſummation in Heauen, when
our dayes on earth ſhall be accompliſhed: And when theſe dayes and nights, which now eat vp our liues, ſhall haue an end, wee may then eſcape the euerlaſting night, and enioy the bleſſed fruition of that bright and ouer-ſhining Day in thy Kingdome, where all our cares and cumbers, our toyles and troubles, our wrongs and oppreſſions ſhall haue an end, where all teares ſhall bee wiped from our eyes, and where with thee, the bleſſed God, the Father, the Sonne, the Holy-Ghoſt, and with Ieſus Chriſt, in our owne fleſh, and with all the Holy Angels, and the Saints gone before vs, wee ſhall receiue the reward of our labours, the iſſue of our hope, the end of our faith, and ſaluation of our ſoules, through the bleſſed and glorious merits of our onely Lord and Sauiour Ieſus Chriſt, in whoſe moſt holy Name we recommend to thy mercy, thy whole Church: and theſe eſpecially, whereof thou haſt
made vs members and beſéech thée for thy ſpeciall bleſſing vpon our gratious Soueraigne the King, the Queene, the Prince, the Prince and Princes Palatine: This whole State and all whom thou haſt ſet ouer vs in Church or commonwealth: vpon the Miniſtery, with our Vniuerſities, the Magiſtracie, with the Iudges, and Innes of Court, vpon our brethren in Virginia, and Sommers Iſlands, and all that helpe to beare thy name vnto the Gentiles: whoſe conuerſion Lord we beſéech thée haſten as alſo the reſtoration of the Iewes, thy ancient and beloued people. As for the Turke and Pope and all the known enemies of thy Grace and Glorie, conuert them Lord if they belong to thee, elſe remooue them out of the way, and let them goe to their owne place. Remember all thy Children afflicted in minde or diſtreſſed in bodie, and all thoſe whom we ought peculiarly to pray for: Lord bleſſe
them and vs, and heare vs for them, and them for vs: and Chriſt Ieſus our glorious Mediatour for vs all: In whoſe Name we offer to thy Maieſtie our ſoules and bodies, and this our poore Morning ſacrifice, in that moſt holy and perfect prayer that hee hath left vs.

OVr Father which art in Heauen, hallowed bee thy Name: Thy Kingdome come: Thy will be done in earth, as it is in Heauen: Giue vs this day our dayly Bread: And forgiue vs our treſpaſſes, as we forgiue them that treſpaſſe againſt vs: And leade vs not into temptation: But deliuer vs from euill: For thine is the Kingdome, the Power, and the Glory, for euer and euer. AMEN.
THe grace of our Lord Ieſus Chriſt, the loue of GOD our Father, and the comfortable fellowſhip of God the Holy-Ghoſt, &c.

div.head: A houſhold Prayer for the Euening.
div.p:
MOſt Mighty Lord GOD, and mercifull Father, the day is thine, and the night is thine, thou haſt created the Light and the Sunne, and cals for darkeneſſe at thy pleaſure: bleſſed for euer be thou, who giues vs the reſt of the night, and comforts of the day: And now wee confeſſe to thy glory, O Lord, that euen for the ſinnes of this day, if thou ſhouldeſt call vs to account, we were not able to abide it, for wee haue ſinned againſt thée this day, both in Omiſſion of good, and in doing of euill, both towards thée, and
towards our brethren, we haue not dealt with others, as we would haue them deale with vs, we haue taken vnlawfull libertie to our ſelues, in thoughts, words and déeds, we haue abuſed thy good creatures to gluttony, drunkenneſſe, wantonneſſe, or exceſſe, we haue delt either negligently or vnfaithfully in our callings: and all this, O Lord, and much more, becauſe wee haue not ſet thée before our eyes, nor nouriſhed thy feare in our hearts. To vs therefore in iuſtice, belongs nothing but ſhame and confuſion. For thou art a righteous and a powerful God, and we confeſſe there is good cauſe, that thy iuſtice ſhould condemne vs, and thy power confound vs; Haue mercie therefore vpon vs O mercifull Father, euen for thy Sonne our Lord Ieſus Chriſts ſake, forgiue vs all that is paſt, and remember that hee came into the world, to ſaue ſinners: we haue ſinned, O Lord, and haue need of thy
mercy: O Lord, ſhew thy mercie vpon vs, and grant vs thy ſaluation: And ſéeing thy promiſes are effectuall to none, but them that beléeue, O LORD, increaſe our Faith in thée, and in all the ſweete promiſes of thy Word, let vs take hold of them, beleeue them, and reſt vpon them in life and death. And foraſmuch as pardon is not giuen but to the penitent, O LORD worke in vs true repentance for all our ſinnes paſt. Let vs ſorrow more for ſinning againſt thee, then for all the wants and miſeries, croſſes and loſſes of this world: And Lord make vs new creatures, worke in vs reformation and amendemnt of life, and euery day wee liue, let vs grow in grace and ſpirituall ſtrength, that as wee are daylie elder, ſo wee may be better, and the nearer wee draw to our ends, grant Lord, wee may draw the neerer to thee, and to euerlaſting happineſſe with thee in
Chriſt Ieſus. And now being reconciled to thee our God, giue vs leaue to call for a bleſſing vpon vs and our labours in our callings this day, for without thee O Lord all is in vaine, though wee riſe earely and goe late to bed, and eate the bread of carefulneſſe: Bleſſe vs therefore moſt bleſſed God, and all the workes of our hands, Lord reward what is well done, and pardon what is amiſſe, giue vs alſo good Lord hearts humbled vnder thy Iudgements, thankefull for thy mercies and contented in our places with the portion thy prouidence aſſignes vnto vs, and teach vs to waite on thee and on thy good prouidence in all our needes and neceſſities of ſoule and body. And let nothing of this world trouble our hearts, O Lord our God, but let vs haue grace to beleeue that thou who haſt giuen Ieſus Chriſt to ſaue vs, canſt deny vs nothing: thus good Lord let vs liue
the life of Faith, whilſt we are héere, that after this life ended, we may receiue the end of our Faith, the ſaluation of our ſoules, through Ieſus Chriſt our Lord. In whoſe Name and mediation wee recommend to thy mercie, thy whole Church, and all whom we any way ought to pray for, as well as if wee had named them particularly: for thou knoweſt them all O Lord, better then wee, and what they néede for ſoule and body, Lord bee mercifull; to them and bleſſe them, as our ſelues, make vs partakers of their prayers, and them of ours, and let thy protection be ouer them and vs, and al ours this night following, giuing vs the reſt and ſléepe thou knoweſt néedfull for theſe poore and vile bodies, and thereby enabling vs to the duties and burdens, which the day following ſhall bring vpon vs. Heare vs for our ſelues good Lord, and for all thine, and for euery one of vs in this family, from
the higheſt to the loweſt, (for with thée is no reſpect of perſons) and anſwere vs in theſe, and all other good bleſſings, which thou knoweſt good for vs, and make vs truely thankefull for thy many good bleſſings, this day, and all our dayes, beſtowed on vs, euen for the merites and blood-ſhedding of Ieſus Chriſt. To whom bleſſed Father, with thee, and the Holy Spirit of Grace, our onely and Eternall God, bee praiſe and glory, now and euermore. Amen.

THe Grace of our Lord Ieſus Chriſt, the loue of God our Father, and the comfortable fellowſhip of God the Holy-Ghoſt, bee with all Gods children, and vs in this family, in our ſoules and bodies, this night, and euermore. Amen.
